document_title: Chronic ischemic heart disease: Causes and treatments
subsection_content:
The disease is recognized through stable angina attacks characterized by: (2)
Location: Usually appears behind the sternum, spreading to the neck, shoulders, jaw, epigastrium, back and hands. There are cases where the pain spreads to the left shoulder, down the inside of the left hand, and then down to the little and ring fingers.; When: Appears when the patient exerts himself, is strongly emotional, is cold, after eating too much or after smoking. In some cases, the pain appears at night, every time the patient changes position or is accompanied by a rapid heartbeat.; Characteristics: The patient feels tightness, pressure or suffocation, sometimes feels cold (medical literature describes angina as if an elephant steps on the chest). The patient may feel fatigue, headache, shortness of breath, sweating and nausea during the pain.
The pain is usually short (3-5 minutes), can be longer but usually does not exceed 20 minutes. In case the pain lasts and appears even at rest, the patient needs to be wary of unstable angina or myocardial infarction. At the same time, with pain that is too short and lasts less than 1 minute, patients need to think about causes other than cardiovascular disease.
“Not all cases of chronic myocardial ischemia have stable angina with typical characteristics. In many cases, patients only feel discomfort in the chest, chest tightness, jaw stiffness when exerting... Therefore, it is recommended that patients be examined early and perform modern imaging diagnostic techniques to be able to diagnose the disease. accurately diagnose the disease," said Dr. Vo Ngoc Cam.
